Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: At the end of the shift, it's time for the routine sweep-up of your designated work area.
Story:
I was sweeping up the last bits of debris at the construction site, the sun already dipping low behind the half-finished building. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my head: “Don’t leave until your area’s spotless. Safety first, always.” I glanced at the clock—just a few more minutes and I’d be done. My phone buzzed in my pocket. It was my stepbrother, waiting for me across the street, waving impatiently. He hated when I was late, but I had to finish my shift properly.

Suddenly, I saw him step off the curb, not even glancing at the traffic. My heart lurched. I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he was safe—Mom’s words from this morning rang in my ears: “He looks up to you. Take care of him.” But if I left my post now, the site wouldn’t be secure, and I’d be letting my crew down, maybe even risking someone’s safety tomorrow. My broom paused mid-sweep, torn between the two worlds, both demanding my attention, both unwilling to wait.
